title: Help! Baby fell of the bed!
opening_message: I'm getting really worried about my 4-month-old baby who just fell off our bed and is showing signs of discomfort with a bump forming on her forehead - I'm not hearing back from her doctor's office and I don't know if I should take her to the ER.

all: My 4-month-old baby has just fallen off a 44cm-high bed and got hurt.
She's developed a bump on her forehead that's still growing, and she's whimpering in distress.
The doctors' office isn't responding to my concerns or providing guidance.
I'm worried about taking her to the ER because of the current COVID-19 surge in our area.
As a parent, I feel uncertain and anxious about making the right decision for my baby's care.
I'm frustrated that the doctors' office isn't being more proactive in addressing my concerns and providing medical advice.

turns.content: I'm getting really worried about my 4-month-old baby who just fell off our bed and is showing signs of discomfort with a bump forming on her forehead - I'm not hearing back from her doctor's office and I don't know if I should take her to the ER.

Oh no, that must be so scary and worrying for you! It sounds like your little one is experiencing some distress after that fall. The bump on her forehead does sound concerning. Have you tried reaching out to a pediatrician's after-hours line or an urgent care center to get some guidance? What are you thinking about doing next if you don't hear back from the office?

I feel so frustrated and helpless, like I'm just not being heard by anyone. I've tried calling the after-hours line multiple times, but all I get is a recording saying they're too busy to take my call. It's like no one cares that my daughter might be in pain or have a serious injury.

I can imagine how frustrating and isolating that must feel for you! It sounds like you're feeling really unheard and overlooked, and that's just not okay. As a mom, it's normal to want someone to talk to and get some reassurance about your baby's well-being. Have you tried reaching out to a close friend or family member who might be able to offer some emotional support while you wait for the doctor's office to get back to you?

Yeah, it's like they're just blowing me off or something. I mean, I'm trying to get some answers about my baby's health and all I get are generic responses and a bunch of scripted questions. It's like they don't actually care that I'm worried sick.

That sounds so infuriating! It's clear that you're desperate for some genuine guidance and reassurance, and it feels like the system is failing you right now. Can you tell me more about what you mean by "scripted questions"? What kind of questions are they asking, and how do you feel like they're not addressing your concerns?

"I'm so frustrated because every time I try to talk to someone about my concerns, they just ask me these scripted questions like 'What's your child's favorite toy?' or 'Have you tried this parenting book?' It feels like they're not actually listening to what I'm saying or trying to understand my situation. And now, with [my daughter] crying and me feeling helpless... it's all just too much."

It sounds like you're feeling really dismissed and unheard by the people who are supposed to be helping you. It's amazing that your frustration is boiling over because of these silly questions when what you really need is someone to take your concerns seriously. Can you think of a specific moment or conversation where you felt like they just weren't listening, and how did that make you feel?

"I'm still replaying the conversation with my pediatrician yesterday, when I was trying to explain how our baby had just taken a nasty fall and they kept interrupting me to ask about my day or if we'd taken them to see anyone else. It felt like they weren't taking my concerns seriously at all, like it was no big deal that my baby could have been seriously injured. And honestly, it made me feel so frustrated and helpless, like I'm just not being heard or understood."

I can imagine how upsetting that must have been for you! It's like they were minimizing the situation and your concerns, instead of taking them seriously. That would be really frustrating, especially when you're already feeling anxious about your baby's well-being. What do you think would make you feel more heard and understood in this situation?

"I guess what would really help is if they just listened to me without interrupting or dismissing my concerns. It feels like they're not taking my baby's needs seriously, and that makes me feel even more anxious about making a mistake. I just want someone to acknowledge that I'm trying my best as a mom and that my baby's well-being matters."

It sounds like you're craving some genuine empathy and understanding from the people who are supposed to be helping you. You just want to be acknowledged for being a good mom, and have your concerns taken seriously. Can you think of any small step you could take today or this week to prioritize taking care of yourself during this stressful time?

Honestly, I'm just feeling so overwhelmed and anxious about taking my kid to the ER with all this going on. The thought of navigating a potentially busy emergency room during a pandemic is just exhausting me. I guess one small step I could take today is to research some local pediatric urgent care options that might be a better fit for our situation, rather than rushing to the ER if it's not absolutely necessary.
